title: Between 16 March 2017 and 16 March 2018, how many countries will submit written notification to the United Nations of their intent to withdraw from the ICC?
preds:
This question is a definitional grey zone.  When the question mentions "between 16 March 2017 and 16 March 2018", is it INCLUSIVE of those dates?? My natural reading would be "No".  If you are AT one point, you are not BETWEEN than point and another. However, the FAQ suggests that the resolution will be "Yes".  The FAQ says, "if the forecasting question asks about an event occurring before 31 December 2015, the deadline is 23:59:59 Pacific on 31 December 2015".  This strongly suggests that terms like BEFORE or BETWEEN are inclusive of the described dates.  It also strongly suggests that we are using PST times unless a question otherwise mentions. A conflict exists between the date in the question (16 March) and the date in the explanation (14 March).  In such a case, it is highly likely that the "explanation" is a typo and will be ignored for purposes of resolution. On that basis, my best guess is that the GJO interpretation will be that the submission WAS before the deadline. However, the submission is of dubious legality, as (if I understand correctly) the Philippines Senate needs to, but has not, ratified the withdrawal.  So has the PHILIPPINES submitted written notification, or has PRESIDENT DUTERTE? My best guess for GJO's interpretation: though the submission might be rejected on this basis by the UN, or might be subsequently retracted by the Philippines Senate, the adjudicators for this question are likely to recognise Duterte (and the Philippines' ambassador) as duly-appointed officers of the Philippines government, and thus yesterday's actions will count as "submit written notification". However, this question will not close and resolve until midnight (PST) tonight (ie. today's forecasts should stand), as there is a (very small) chance a 2nd nation could submit written notification in the next 4 hours! *************************
CONFLICT OF INTEREST
Minimal either way for me.  I entered this question late (mid-Feb), and have been with the Consensus throughout.

It looks like written notification was submitted: https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2018/03/16/1797330/philippines-formally-informs-un-icc-withdrawal I am screwed on this question. Philippines submits on last day. I assume the question means that it is inclusive of 16 March.

It is done: Philippines informs U.N. of ICC withdrawal, court regrets move “The government affirms its commitment to fight against impunity for atrocity crimes, notwithstanding its withdrawal from the Rome Statute, especially since the Philippines has a national legislation punishing atrocity crimes,” the government said in a letter dated Thursday and addressed to the U.N. secretary-general.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-duterte-icc-un/philippines-informs-u-n-of-icc-withdrawal-court-regrets-move-idUSKCN1GS0Y5

I think Duerte needs to submit a Depository Notice in formal communications with the Secretary General of UN, and it still doesn't look like he has done this step. The question says: "...submit written notification to UN" He has publicized a written 15-pager but this seems more like a worldwide press release than an actual intent. https://treaties.un.org/doc/Publication/CN/2016/CN.786.2016-Eng.pdf
Thought Duterte would be able to get out but the senate is blocking him
7 min prior to midnight and a google search brings up only references that the Philippines "will withdraw", "plans to withdraw", etc.

I sadly forgot to update / lower my forecast before going to bed. Reduced the 100% to 50% now. I think Duterte is absolutely serious about it and that this matter is done, however: He might just don't care to go the formal way.

But in a 15-page statement, dated March 13, Duterte said he was withdrawing from the ICC’s founding treaty, the Rome Statute, because of “baseless, unprecedented and outrageous attacks” by U.N. officials, and ICC actions that he said failed to follow due process and presumption of innocence. “There appears to be a concerted effort on the part of the U.N. special rapporteurs to paint me as a ruthless and heartless violator of human rights who allegedly caused thousands of extrajudicial killings,” Duterte said. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-duterte-icc/duterte-to-withdraw-philippines-from-icc-after-outrageous-attacks-idUSKCN1GQ0MA?il=0 @shivadiva It seems there is no formal paperwork lodged though, but I believe the Punisher will deliver.
Nothing done by Duerte in writing so far  https://treaties.un.org/Pages/CNs.aspx?cnTab=tab2&clang=_en

Also of note: While the questions says, "Between 16 March 2017 and 16 March 2018 ...", the more detailed explanation says, "Any country that submits a notification between 14 March 2017 and 14 March 2018 will count ..." It is currently 1930 on the evening of the 14th in NYC, so presumably there will be no written notification today. Will Duterte follow through?  And in the next couple of days in writing?  Hmmm ... it's not 0% ...

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/14/world/asia/rodrigo-duterte-philippines-icc.html?emc=edit_mbae_20180314&nl=&nlid=7782502520180314&te=1 "In a written statement released on Wednesday, Mr. Duterte accused the court of violating “due process and the presumption of innocence.”
. . .
"Mr. Duterte said he was withdrawing the Philippines immediately from the Rome Statute, which established the International Criminal Court. The statute says that a withdrawal cannot take effect for at least a year, but Mr. Duterte said that provision was invalid because there had been “fraud” when the Philippines joined the treaty.
. . . .
"For a country to withdraw from the court, it must formally notify the United Nations secretary general of its decision. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT: (I am making the assumption that the NY Times is careful in its word selection.) I note that the articles says that "a written statement" was released, that's different from a letter formally notifying the UN Sec Gen of intent to withdraw.  I also notice that the article says Duterte "was withdrawing the Philippines" (future tense), not that he "had withdrawn".

Just today, the Philippines announced that it will withdraw from International Criminal Court. https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/14/asia/philippines-international-criminal-court-intl/index.html The announcement was made but will written notification be handed this that quickly? Guess not. Right?
Why has Duterte chosen to do this now? Is he a secret forecaster trying to game the system?

Per others, verbal <> written so unlikely as Duterte is too busy riding around on his Harley engaging in extrajudicial killings to put pen to paper.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/14/rodrigo-duterte-to-pull-philippines-out-of-international-criminal-court-icc

I didn't expect a cliffhanger. Duterte has two days to submit written notification. Philippine law requires consent of Senate to revoke an international treaty. Might Duterte submit written notification even if it is not binding? He only has two days.

Duterte to withdraw Philippines from ICC for 'violations of due process'
https://uk.mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUKKCN1GQ0MD
Timing is pretty tight though for written notification...

While countries have threatened to leave the ICC the current trend has been for them to back track. And many that had threatened to leave have said that they would not. Leaving the ICC remains an anomaly.
4 days until the end of the question, adjusted from 99% to 100%.
So late to the question that I have to go all in.

Since the Rome Statute was adopted in 1998 (233 months ago), there have been a total of THREE submitted notifications of intent to withdraw.  All of these appear to have been in the setting about protest about the same issue: the disproportionate application of the Statute to African leaders.  That issue is no longer the "hot topic" that it was 12-18 months ago. The chance of notification of intent to withdraw in the next month is very low.
as of today only Belgium proposing an amendment

One month to go and all I'm reading about is talk. But since talk is cheap and I've been reading about countries threatening to withdraw since the ICC was founded I don't think much changes in the next month.

No recent developments regarding the African countries that had previously threatened to withdraw.   There was, however, news this week that the ICC will begin to investigate Duterte for drug war killings in the Philippines. Duterte had said last year that he'd withdraw from the ICC but later retreated.  The ICC "examination" of the government's involvement in the killings will take a while  and March 16 is around he corner.
Domestic political turmoil makes it unlikely (although not impossible) that additional states will follow through on the AU's proposal for mass withdrawal by the closing date.

Baseline : No notifications since 14 March 2017 on UN treaty sites
History : Burundi, Gambia and South Africa asked to withdraw. Gambia and South Africa withdrew the request before the 14th March 2017.
South Africa’s reason was because the courts forced the (corrupt?) government to do so. Reports in Daily Maverick place South Africa minister of justice (Michel Masutha) in New York in December to say his government will put before parliament a new withdrawal notice…
International Criminal Crimes bill was indeed tabled in the South Africal parliament mid December 2017. This bill, if passed, would remove legal motive to oppose withdrawal from the ICC (indeed such withdrawal is a stated purpose of the bill). Parliamentary opposition says it will not pass unchallenged.
I’ve not been able to find any source for the status of the Bill in the South African parliament…
Also, the State of the Nation address that was to be given by President Zuma on Feb 9th has been postponed until after a parliamentary no-confidence vote scheduled for Feb 22nd.
This date is only three weeks from the question’s resolution date, so even if Zuma were to win the no-confidence vote, he would not be able to get the bill passed and send the withdrawal notice to the ICC before the deadline.
Kenya’s announced plan for withdrawal on standby / inactive since political scandal… I may of course have missed something though… so I’ll go with 99% for 0 states and 1% for 1 state
I don’t see any recent events that would motivate a nation to withdraw.
havent seen anything lately about mass withdrawal. South Africa too preoccupied with leadership (plus a couple things called judiciary and parliament). Gambia retracted.

The ICC moves too slowly for exit to have a payout to anyone that would submit that decision.  This part of elite behavior, compared to others that are exposed to revolt against elites, is safe for the time being.

There have only ever been 3 notifications of intents to withdraw since the Rome statute came into force. 2 of the 3 were rescinded, only Burundi remains as having an outstanding notification. The wider proposal for all African Union members to withdraw had strong support from Kenya but the leadership supporting that proposal has since  been mired in some degree of displeasure and not made any noises about withdrawal. It is unlikely that any moves in this direction would be made by other countries in the absence of a strong African nation doing so (South Africa having since withdrawn their notice).
Not a good group to be part of (withdrawal). Court is working on compromises based on perceptions.
Shifting further toward zero due to passage of time.

African Union (AU) recommends mass withdrawal of African nations from the ICC.  The AU is not a member of the ICC, and each country must make its own decision.  Concern is that most ICC prosecutions are against Africans. However the main intent is to change the ICC from inside, while threatening to leave.  Eventually it seems there will be additional withdrawals if negotiations inside the ICC fail to make progress.
http://www.dw.com/en/will-au-members-really-withdraw-from-the-icc/a-37374040 Current Situation (Oct. 2017):
http://www.africanews.com/2017/10/27/burundi-is-officially-not-a-member-of-the-international-criminal-court-icc// Top candidates: 
Burundi - already left
South Africa - effort declared unconstitutional by S African Count. Upcoming election make short term "notification" unlikely.
Kenya - ICC charges dropped, although the ICC still interested: http://www.pulselive.co.ke/election/2017/news/icc-issues-fresh-warning-to-uhuru-id7518832.html
The Gambia - new leaders revolked notification.
Rwanda and Kenyan leaders to oppose ICC through the AU.
Uganda - First, Uganda more supportive once ICC comes to Uganda looking for Joseph Koni. Second, Ugandan elected to the ICC court: http://www.nation.co.ke/news/africa/Uganda-judge-Solome-Bossa-joins-the-ICC-in-The-Hague/1066-4216530-p4x6miz/index.html
Zambia - referendum indicates 93% in favor of remaining in ICC.
Shifting toward zero due to passage of time.

Limited amount  of time left till March 2018 and no withdrawals.
https://treaties.un.org/Pages/CNs.aspx?cnTab=tab2&clang=_en
Adjusting on the basis of the base rate as elucidated by @Raahul_Kumar at http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/614929
Shifting back to my original guess because I didn't realize Burundi doesn't count because they withdrew last year.

Any country that submits a notification between 14 March 2017 and 14 March 2018 will count, regardless of whether it later withdraws that notification. Burundi has withdrawn, but it left in 2016. No nation has since withdrawn, except South Africa did and didn't. https://www.theguardian.com/law/2017/oct/28/burundi-becomes-first-nation-to-leave-international-criminal-court https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/08/world/africa/south-africa-icc-withdrawal.html It has not submitted a new withdrawal since Mar 14.
adjusting some, thanks to @raisinville, who pointed out that burundi's notification happened last year, to become effective now.  still expecting a couple more dropouts to sign out, perhaps.

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/burundi-leave-international-criminal-court-171027080533712.html
Have to wait a few days to see whether this is a one-off or the beginning of a rush for the exit.  Stay tuned.

Burundi gave notification last year. Burundi will be out of the court on 27 October. South Africa and Zambia withdrew their notifications. Russia gave notice that it would not become a party to the treaty, but Russia had never ratified the treaty.  http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/open-a-case-against-burundi-as-soon-as-possible-icc-told-20170904 I can't find anyone else who has threatened to withdraw. But I'm not sure how I would find out if any one of 127 countries were contemplating withdrawal.
So far there haven't been any and we are more than halfway through the time frame.

There doesn't seem to be any initiative. States are more likely to do their best to ignore the court for now. https://thewire.in/163250/south-africa-icc-sudan-president-omar-al-bashir-international-cooperation/

Shifting down a bit because surprisingly not a single country has actually pulled out. Of the four countries (Kenya, Namibia, South Africa, and Uganda) that have made noises about pulling out, none seems to be advancing the process. That said, I still think it is possible that at least one will.

As the African National Congress (ANC) national policy conference wraps up and commissions report back, the party has made clear its decision to withdraw from the Rome Statute. The ANC says government should continue to exhaust all legal processes for South Africa to withdraw from the International Criminal Court (ICC).
http://ewn.co.za/2017/07/05/anc-dead-set-on-withdrawing-from-icc

There have been some key indicators another African nation could withdraw but that's a big "IF". If it does happen, given the backlash S. Africa and Gambia received from their submissions, the number won't likely be more than 1.

Passage of time means the higher numbers are out and it might be done to just 1 or 2. South Africa is still supposed to withdraw, but no news on that front.
https://treaties.un.org/Pages/CNs.aspx?cnTab=tab2&clang=_en

There are a few possibility for withdrawal but none really seem likely. First, I worry about the ICC opening an investigation in the Philippines and Duterte subsequently withdrawing. Second, I worry about African countries, either as a group or individually, leaving. However, the African Union resolution about the ICC agreed at their latest summit is, well, less than meets the eye. It ended up calling more for consultation than withdrawal so I'm not really worried that a whole bunch of countries leave. Although there are a couple that worry me, such as Burundi, the DR Congo, and maybe even Kenya. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-38826073
Because Justice​ almost absent from U N
If I can call it as Trump effect
The world is busy with new major issues.  It gives more chance for dictatorships to withdraw quietly
Trying to approximate a bell curve, with a slight overweight in the 2 to 5 area.
Feels like at least a couple of dictators will want to reduce chances of international scrutiny.

Zambia is deciding on whether to withdraw from the ICC Chipenzi Labels Consultation on ICC Withdrawal a Mockery
https://zambiareports.com/2017/03/27/chipenzi-labels-consultation-icc-withdrawal-mockery/ The ICC can’t live with Africa, but it can’t live without it either
http://www.nation.co.ke/oped/Opinion/ICC-Africa-member-states/440808-3863784-10y0pguz/

Not convinced that there will be a mass exodus of African Union countries. Most African countries favor pursuing reforms for the time being. Next AU Summit should be in a few months. Will update forecast at that time. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-38826073

The White Court to punish Blacks must be disbanded. There cannot be a continuation of the Western order where only blacks are lynched at white whims. The 123-member ICC, in operation since 2002, has issued nine indictments, all against Africans
https://thewire.in/14836/did-india-just-sound-the-death-knell-of-the-international-criminal-court/ I am proud to state that Bharat has fought against the ICC since its inception. Most powerful nations aren't even members. It is an impotent and irrelevant. http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl1807/18070670.htm Masutha's spokesperson Mthunzi Mhaga said the bill was withdrawn purely to comply with the court ruling. "It is purely in compliance with the court order," he said, adding that the bill would be reintroduced at a later stage and the parliamentary processes would unfold around these again.
http://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2017/03/14/justice-minister-withdraws-bill-that-would-take-south-africa-out/ Last week, in the portfolio committee on international relations, ANC MP Bheki Hadebe warned that the withdrawal from the Rome Statute would be back on Parliament's agenda in a year’s time.
http://www.iol.co.za/capetimes/minister-withdraws-icc-bill-8193844 Russia withdraws signature from international criminal court statute 
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/nov/16/russia-withdraws-signature-from-international-criminal-court-statute African Union (AU) issued a resolution, based on a decision taken the day before, encouraging member nations to withdraw from the International Criminal Court (ICC)
https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/african-union-resolution-urges-states-to-leave-icc/
In a time of increasing populism and nationalism the ICC will probably receive more notifications, how many?
These are off the top of my head, such as it is.  Rounding up suspects over the next couple of days.
